Los miembros del grupo desempeñan distintas actividades como medios de vida para sacar adelante a su familia: Francisca se dedica a la cría de marranos, servicio de molino y venta de abarrotes; Alejandra a la venta de lencería, cosméticos y carne de pollo; Mayte y María  a la venta de tamales; Teresa, a la venta de comida y servicio de sastre; Josefina, a la venta de tamales y refrescos; Mayra, a la venta de comida; Felipa, a la venta de refacciones para automóvil; Demetria, a la elaboración de tejidos y costuras; Susana, a la venta de cosméticos; Yomali, a la venta de ropa y calzado por catálogo y José, a la venta de verduras. 

Desde hace 14 años, Francisca se dedica a la cría y venta de puercos, su actividad principal, pues vio la necesidad de apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de sus dos hijos y de tener un ingreso propio. Pronto, utilizó sus ahorros para comprar un molino y rentarlo a sus vecinos además de comenzar a vender masa. 

Nuevamente, Francisca utilizó sus ganancias para emprender otro negocio. Viendo la necesidad de las comunidades más alejadas y de difícil acceso, comenzó a comprar productos básicos por mayoreo y formar pequeñas despensas para distribuir los fines de semana acompañada de su esposo. 

Francisca necesita comprar más maíz para sus animales y una marrana con el objetivo de tener más lechones en algunos meses. Ella se siente satisfecha por la actividad que tiene durante todos los días de la semana y agradece el apoyo de los préstamos que le han permitido mantener sus negocios, la mercancía y animales suficientes. Las ganancias también le han ayudado a mejorar sus condiciones de vida: ha renovado los muebles de su hogar y ha podido pagar con mayor facilidad los gastos de educación de sus hijos. 

Las ganas de salir adelante continúan presentes en Francisca y ya piensa en otra actividad, le encantaría vender antojitos los fines de semana después de la venta de despensas. 

*En la imagen, las integrantes posando en el jardín de la oficina de VisionFund México. Francisca viste blusa de escotada color negro y se encuentra de pie detrás de María quien viste blusa color café.
texts.en:
On the way to visit the communal bank group La Sorpresa, one can see plantations of sugarcane, banana and corn as well as fruit vendors along the road; and every now and then a few words in Mazateco can be heard.

The members of the group work in different activities to earn a living for their families.  Francisca raises pigs, runs a mill and sells groceries; Alejandra sells lingerie, cosmetics and chicken; Mayte and Maria sell tamales; Teresa sells food and has a sewing business; Josefina sells tamales and soft drinks; Mayra sells food; Felipa sells auto spare parts, weaves and sews; Susana sells cosmetics; Yomali sells clothing and shoes by catalogue; and Jose sells vegetables. 

For 14 years Francisca has been raising and selling pigs, which is her main business.  She felt the need to support her husband to cover the expenses of their two children, and wanted to her own income.  Soon, she used her savings to buy a mill to rent out to neighbors and she started selling dough.

Then Francisca used her profits to start another business.  Seeing the need of the most remote communities, where access is difficult, she began to buy basic goods, wholesale, and started putting together small packages to distribute on weekends with her husband.

Francisca needs to buy more corn for her animals and a sow to have more piglets in a few months.  She is satisfied with the activity she has every day of the week and is grateful to the lenders who have allowed her to keep her business running by having sufficient merchandise and animals.  The profit she has earned has improved her living conditions: she has bought new furniture for her home and been able to pay for her children's education much easier.

The desire to get ahead is ever present in Francisca's mind and she is already thinking about a new business.  She would love to sell snack foods on the weekends after delivering the packages.

*The picture of the members of the group was taken in the garden of the VisionFund Mexico offices.  Francisca is wearing a black top and standing behind Maria who is in a toffee-colored top.

loans.use: To buy corn and a sow to raise.

loans.name: Santa Lucrecia Group

texts.es:
El lugar donde se conformó el grupo Santa Lucrecia es conocido como La Novia del Sol debido a la gran ola de calor que está presente la mayor parte del año. Cada uno de los integrantes desempeña una actividad económica como medio de vida: 

Roxana, Susana y Reyna – Venta de Cosméticos 
Alicia – Venta de Ropa, Queso, Mole, Camarón, Totopos y Cosméticos
Teresa M. – Venta de Ropa y Productos para el Hogar
Catalina y Leticia L. – Venta de Ropa 
Julia – Venta de Productos Naturistas y Cosméticos
Liliana – Venta de Cosméticos Y Lencería
María Eugenia – Venta de Refrescos y Dulces
Leticia M. – Venta de Antojitos, Blusas Y Zapatos
Alfredo y Alberto – Servicio De Taxi
Hilaria – Venta de Comida, Miel, Mole Y Raspados
María Esther – Venta de Joyería de Fantasía y Accesorios
Eloina – Venta de Carne, Chicharrón Y Barbacoa 
María de Lourdes – Venta de Bolsas
Brenda y Rosa – Venta de Comida

Doña Alicia tiene 63 años de edad, es madre de 4 hijos, todos ellos profesionistas  gracias al trabajo y esfuerzo que realizaron ella y su esposo quien lamentablemente falleció hace 7 meses.

A los 23 años, Alicia comenzó su actividad motivada por su madre quien entonces preparaba la pasta de mole. Ahora, es Alicia quien, siguiendo la antigua receta, deleita los paladares de vecinos y conocidos. 

Al casarse, Alicia continuó con la venta de mole, pero también comenzó a vender trajes típicos del estado de Chiapas, queso, totopos y camarones, productos que desde entonces compra cada dos meses directamente en Chiapas. Hace apenas 4 meses también comenzó a vender cosméticos en su tiempo libre. En unos días doña Alicia viajará a Chiapas para comprar más productos y para ello empleará su préstamo. 

Alicia no deja sus metas a un lado, con ayuda de sus hijos planea comenzar a etiquetar la pasta de mole para ampliar su mercado. “El truco está en levantarnos con más fuerza cada vez que caemos” comenta Alicia quien siempre motiva a sus compañeras y amigas del grupo para se sigan esforzando y mejorando sus negocios.

*La fotografía fue capturada fuera de la casa de doña Alicia quien lleva un vestido negro con blanco y usa lentes.
texts.en:
The location where the bank group Santa Lucrecia established itself is known as "La Novia del Sol" (the Sun's Bride) because of the hot temperatures that are present throughout most of the year.  Each of the members is involved in a business activity:

Roxana, Susana and Reyna – Cosmetics  
Alicia – Sales of cothing, cheese, mole, shrimp, totopos and cosmetics
Teresa M. – Sales of clothing and household products
Catalina and Leticia L. – Clothing
Julia – Sales of natural products and cosmetics
Liliana – Sales of cosmetics and lingerie
María Eugenia – Sales of soft drinks and sweets
Leticia M. – Sales of snacks, blouses and shoes
Alfredo and Alberto – Taxi service
Hilaria – Sales of food, honey, mole and iced drinks 
María Esther – Sales of costume jewelry and accessories
Eloina – Sales of meat, pork and barbecue cuts 
María de Lourdes – Sales of bags
Brenda y Rosa – Sales of food

Alicia, 63, is the mother of four children.  They are all professionals thanks to the work and efforts of Alicia and her husband, who passed away unfortunately seven months ago.

At age 23, Alicia was encouraged by her mother to start a mole (thick chile sauce) business.  Now it is Alicia who follows an old recipe to delight the palates of neighbors and friends.

After marrying, Alicia continued to sell mole, but she also started selling typical dress from the state of Chiapas, as well as cheese, totopos and shrimp.  Now, every two months she buys the products in Chiapas directly.  Around four months ago she started selling cosmetics in her free time.  In a few days Alicia will travel to Chiapas to buy more products for which she needs a loan. 

*The picture was taken outside Alicia's house.  She is in a black and white dress and wearing glasses.

loans.use: To buy clothing, cheese, totopos (corn tortillas) and shrimp.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to grow rice then sell it

loans.name: Juvenil Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad ubicada entre plantaciones de caña donde aún quedan vestigios de la cultura mazateca se formó un grupo llamado Juvenil. Los miembros desempeñan una actividad con los objetivos de desarrollarse y mejorar poco a poco las condiciones de vida de su familia. Ellos son: Venancio quien se dedica a la venta de madera; Karina, a la venta de perfumes; Jazmín, Azucena y María, a la venta de productos para el hogar; Luz, a la venta de tiempo aire y accesorios para celular; Silvino, a la elaboración y venta de prendas tejidas y Graciela quien tiene una papelería. 

Silvino de 55 años de edad es una persona carismática y muy apreciada en su comunidad. Mudo de nacimiento, se dedica a tejer blusas, manteles, servilletas y vestidos, actividad que aprendió de su madre desde los 10 años. Por las tardes, Silvino se sienta debajo de la sombra de un árbol de mango y comienza a tejer o bordar. Tiene clientes que le llevan los hilos de su preferencia y sólo les cobra la mano de obra. Los productos que elabora los vende en su comunidad o en las más cercanas.

A través de señas y gestos, don Silvino expresó que el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de bastidores, ganchos e hilos para terminar un pedido de un mantel de 2 metros de largo. Su sueño, es aprender a realizar bordados mazatecos.

*La fotografía tomada en casa de Jazmín, don Silvino viste camisa azul a cuadros y como de costumbre anda descalzo.
texts.en:
In a community nestled between sugar cane plantations, where relics of the Mazatec people still remain, the “Juvenil” loan group has been created. The members of this group work in order to progress and gradually improve their and their families’ quality of life. These members are: Venancia, who makes a living selling wood; Karina, sells perfumes; Jazmín, Azucena and María, who make a living selling household products; Luz, sells phone credit and mobile phone accessories; Silvino, produces and sells woven goods; and Graciela, who owns a stationery shop.

Silvino is 55 years old and a charismatic man who is much-loved in his local community. Mute since birth, he weaves blouses, tablecloths, napkins and dresses, a trade that he began learning from his mother when he was ten years old. In the afternoon, Silvino sits in the shade of a mango tree, and begins to weave and sew. He has customers who bring him their favourite threads; Silvino only charges these customers for labour costs.  Silvino sells the products he makes in his community and in nearby areas.

Through signs and gestures, Silvino explains that he will use this loan to buy stretchers, hooks and threads in order to finish an order for a two-metre-long tablecloth. Silvino’s dream is to learn to do Mazatec embroidery work.

*The photograph was taken at Jazmín’s house. In it, Silvino is wearing a blue checked shirt and, as is his custom, walks barefoot.

loans.use: to buy stretchers, hooks and threads.

loans.name: Athanasie

texts.en:
Athanasie is 25-years-old married with one child age of 2 years. She is a farmer, and  she has been producing rice for 8 years. Her husband is a business man. 

With the loan from Kiva, Athanasie would like to buy more fertilizers to enable her to grow and sell rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her child, and to buy a piece of land.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers, to enable her to grow and sell rice

loans.name: Las Agradables Group

texts.es:
La principal fuente de ingresos de la comunidad  donde viven los integrantes del grupo Las Agradables es la agricultura. La caña de azúcar es el cultivo principal aunque también hay productos alternativos como arroz, maíz, frijol, sorgo, piña y mango. El grupo de préstamo está conformado por Julia quien vende abarrotes; Reyna y Daría, perfumes; Dulce, sábanas; Ángela, comida, refrescos y papelería; Paula, abarrotes y Agustín quien ofrece servicio de taxi. 

Agustín cuenta con 36 años de experiencia tras el volante. Al casarse, sabía que había adquirido una gran responsabilidad y compromiso, momento en que decidió comenzar a trabajar como chofer para otra persona. Finalmente, después de 30 años de trabajo e invirtiendo sus ahorros Agustín cumplió su meta de obtener la autorización para ofrecer el servicio con su propio automóvil. 

Lo que más le gusta de su actividad a Agustín es el contacto con las personas, conocer diferentes comunidades y los límites entre los estados donde circula. Él comienza a transitar a partir de las 5 am y se detiene hasta las 9 pm. Después de este horario sólo hace viajes especiales para algunas personas. 

“Gracias a mi trabajo como taxista y el apoyo de mi esposa, mi hijo está cursando el 4º semestre de Ingeniería Industrial” para don Agustín es fundamental brindarle las mejores oportunidades a su familia. 

Con su tercer préstamo de VisionFund México cambiará las 4 llantas de su automóvil para seguir brindando el mejor servicio sin ningún riesgo. Dentro de sus planes a futuro, le gustaría tener otro taxi y establecer una tienda de abarrotes en su propia casa. 

*En la imagen: los integrantes del grupo en su comunidad donde se alcanza a ver el taxi de Agustín.
texts.en:
Farming is the main source of income in the community where the “Las Agradables” group members live. The main crop is sugar, though other products, such as rice, corn, beans, sorghum, pineapples and mangoes are grown too. 

The “Los Agradables” loan group comprises the following members: Julia, who sells groceries; Reyna and Daría, both of whom sell perfumes; Dulce, sells bedsheets; Ángela, who sells meals, soft drinks and stationery products; and Agustín, a taxi driver.

Agustín has 36 years’ experience behind the steering wheel. When he got married, he knew that he had taken on a big responsibility and made a big commitment and it was then that he decided to start working as a driver. After working for somebody else for 30 years, Agustín invested his savings and achieved one of his goals when he acquired his own taxi licence and began driving his own taxi.

What Agustín most likes about this work is being in contact with people; he gets to know different communities and the borders between the different states where he drives. Agustín starts work at 5am and finishes at 9pm. After this day at work, he only does special journeys for some people.

Agustín says, “Thanks to my work as a taxi driver and the support of my wife, my son is in his fourth semester studying for a degree in industrial engineering.” For Agustín, it is essential that he offer his family better opportunities in life.

Agustín will use this third loan from VisionFund México to replace the four tyres of his vehicle in order to continue offering good, safe service. In the future, Agustín would like to have another taxi, and open a grocery store in his own house.

*The photo of the members of the group was taken in their local community. Augstín’s taxi is also visible.

loans.use: to buy new tyres and to pay for alignment and the lining up of the wheels of his vehicle.

loans.name: Angela Maria

texts.es:
Angela es una mujer de 48 años de edad, ella es separada de su esposo, con él tuvo tres hijos masculinos dos de ellos adolescentes y uno menor de edad, como se puede ver en la foto la señora Angela oferta en un rincón de su sala productos como frituras, galletas, chocolates, dulces, algunos abarrotes y papel higiénico, ella es una mujer muy humilde que inicio esta actividad por mera necesidad económica, no cuenta con un empleo, pensión, entrada de dinero u ayuda monetaria alguna, solo con sus productos, sus ganancias mejorar cuando su salud le permite salir a vender los productos en la calle. 

Lo que más espera Angela es poder pagar la educación de sus hijos que viven con ella, son su razón de trabajar y lo hace orgullosamente para mantenerlos y verlos siempre sonreír sin preocupación alguna.

Solicita un préstamo que invertirá en la compra de surtido de abarrotes, y productos de aseo doméstico, la necesidad es clara, se puede apreciar en la foto, ayúdala, ella te lo agradecerá de corazón.
texts.en:
Angela, age 48, is separated from her husband.  They have three sons.  Two of them are adolescents, and one is younger.  As can be seen in the photo, Angela sells products like snacks, cookies, chocolate, sweets, some groceries, and toilet paper from a corner in her living room.

She is a very humble woman who started this business activity out of pure financial need.  She does not have a job, a pension, an influx of money, or any kind of monetary help.  She only gets income with her products.  Her earnings improve when her health allows her to go out and sell the products on the street.

What Angela wishes for the most is to be able to pay for her children’s education.  Her children live with her.  They are her reason for working.  Supporting them and always seeing them smile without any worries makes her feel proud.

She is requesting a loan to buy stock of groceries and household cleaning products.  The need is clear, as can be seen in the photo.  Help her.  She will thank you will all of her heart.

loans.use: to buy stock of groceries and household cleaning products.

loans.name: Idayat

texts.ru: Идаят, 52 года, вдова, 4 детей. У Идаят среднее образование. В качестве основного рода деятельности она с 1989 года стала заниматься животноводством. Благодаря упорному труду Идаят, в хозяйстве имеется: 2 коровы, 16 овец и лошадь. Сельскохозяйственная деятельность приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, она обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 35,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота для откорма и реализации. Доходы от кредита Идаят планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение своего хозяйства.
texts.en: Idayat is 52 years old, a widow, and the mother of four children.  She has a secondary education.  She became involved in animal husbandry in 1989 as her main activity.  Thanks to her very hard work, she currently has two cows, 16 sheep and one horse on her farm.  Her farming business brings her about 10,000 som (KGS).  Eager to further grow her business, she has turned to Bai Tushum and requested a loan of 35,000 som (KGS) to buy some livestock for fattening and resale.  She is planning to use the earnings from her loan to further develop her activity.

loans.use: to purchase some livestock for fattening and resale.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Purity is 30 years old. She is married and blessed with one child. She has a beauty salon and also sells beauty products, a business she has done for five years now.

Purity is taking her second loan with VisionFund Kenya. She plans to use the loan to purchase a blow drier for use in her salon and also add more stock of beauty products such as hair cream and oil, hair chemicals and lotions. 

She hopes to make more income and be able to provide for the needs of her family as well as improve their living standards. 

In future Purity hopes to expand her business,make more income and be financially stable.

loans.use: to purchase a blow drier and beauty products
